awd_titl_txt: IGE: Learning the Entire Pipeline: Analyzing and Improving Graduate Engineering Education through Communities of Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to North Carolina State University will support groundbreaking research on how graduate students in critical Engineering domains learn to put academic knowledge into practice while working in diverse, interdisciplinary teams.  In order to prepare students to transfer their classroom experiences to professional practice, engineering education needs to improve students’ ability to work in multidisciplinary teams, deal with diverse opinions, ideas, and backgrounds, and broaden their education to understand the impact of engineering solutions in a global context. This project adopts a highly developed theoretical framework called “communities of practice” (CoP) and applies, researches, and further extends CoP theory in graduate classes across Civil Engineering, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering. This approach has a strong emphasis on collaboration, teamwork, knowledge as doing, and communication across disciplinary and cultural backgrounds. 

By applying this approach in three engineering courses from three different engineering departments at North Carolina State University, this project will yield insights around student interactions and learning within different team settings: 1) integration into a professional engineering environment, studying how students interact with professionals and how the academic and professional communities learn from their encounters; 2) engagement in interdisciplinary projects in teams that bring together two disciplinary communities; and 3) engagement in interdisciplinary projects with teams that work on subsystems which need to be integrated into one working whole. This project will focus on how diversity plays out in CoPs, examine what factors lead to productive participation by all, what challenges inhibit participation and investigate approaches to structuring academic CoPs to support equitable learning and contributions by all. Through this approach which involves various settings and granularities in three different courses, this project will develop a broader view of how engineering students learn in different team settings. The proposed approach can help to bridge the gap between theory and practice, facilitating the development of a workforce that can work within and across teams, projects, and domains. To help apply the proposed approaches to other disciplines, we will develop and disseminate a set of guidelines in our future publications and presentations. 

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test, and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a pressing need to develop pedagogical theory and practice to improve the readiness for the workforce of STEM graduates.  Research shows that many recent graduates in STEM fields, particularly in engineering, feel unprepared for the workforce. Similarly, employers often find that graduates lack essential skills such as collaboration, teamwork, communication, and the ability to work across multiple disciplines.Engineering graduate students must learn to apply academic knowledge into practice while working in diverse teams and collaborating with teams in other fields. 

This NSF-funded project aimed to address this workforce-readiness problem by generating both theoretical knowledge and practical strategies to improve training programs for engineering students. Our goal was to better prepare students to engage in collaboration, communicate effectively across disciplinary boundaries, and develop the skills needed to succeed in diverse professional environments, and understand how students’ demographic characteristics might impact their participation in order to develop approaches to better support all students.

This project researched three highly interactive and interdisciplinary graduate engineering courses: Educational Data Mining, Design of a Robotic Computer Vision System for Autonomous Navigation, and Building Information Modeling in Construction, grounded in the theoretical framework of Communities of Practice (CoP). The project applied CoP theory to analyze the classes, developed and evaluated practical enhancements designed to bridge the gap between industry expectations and the capabilities of recent graduates, and refined and extended CoP theory for formal academic STEM settings. Between the applied and theoretical advancements generated by the project, the education of engineers who are better equipped to meet the demands of today’s workforce will be enhanced.

The research process involved qualitative analyses of multiple data sources including interviews, field observations, classroom assignments, and student course evaluations. Quantitative social network analyses complemented and were triangulated with the qualitative analyses. CoP theory was advanced and refined by conducting analyses across all three classes, which varied by size of teams, degree of interdisciplinarity, and forms of connecting to the workforce, allowing for generalization of findings.

In a pedagogical interdisciplinary study currently under major revision at a top-tier Q1 journal, the International Journal of STEM Education, we utilized empirical data from two iterations of the EDM course to develop a conceptual framework for designing courses that foster transdisciplinarity, interdisciplinarity, and multidisciplinarity. Our research identified effective strategies for instructors to act as "brokers," connecting diverse disciplines and supporting students in engaging with interdisciplinary course components.

In the Work-Integrated Learning (WIL) paper, published in Higher Education, a leading Q1 journal in the field, we analyzed data from the BIM course to explore the integration of workplace learning into academic curricula. This work proposed a new conceptualization and definition of the purpose and pedagogical implications of WIL experiences. In a follow-up article, currently under major revision in Higher Education, we provided evidence-based best practices for implementing WIL and proposed a scaffolding learning model designed to address inequities in participation. By defining different types of university-industry connections, we demonstrated how WIL agreements can be tailored to meet diverse student needs.

In a mixed-methods study titled Analyzing the Functioning of a Graduate Engineering Class with Multiple Collaborating Groups Using Slack: An Embedded Mixed Methods Research, we examined the implementation of a Robotics course to develop a conceptual and operational model for evaluating student participation in highly collaborative class environments. Our findings provide foundational guidance for designing courses where students collaborate both within and across teams, offering a roadmap for fostering effective teamwork in engineering education.

Our theoretical contributions and the improvements made to these courses have the potential to impact not only the field of engineering education but also other STEM disciplines, providing a model for how to better prepare students for the challenges of the modern professional landscape.
